Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Elements of an extinction: Exploring the delayed Caribbean extinction with stable isotopes and trace elements
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists warn that the current degradation and fragmentation of ecosystems will lead to extinctions long into the future -- a process dubbed 'Extinction debt' --but making accurate predictions requires a much better understanding of how extinctions occur over long-term time scales. This project will dissect the Plio-Pleistocene extinction event (1-2 Myr) in the southwestern Caribbean (SWC) to examine the relationship between environmental perturbation and extinction rate. During the Plio-Pleistocene event, extinction rates peaked between 35 and 100% in a variety of marine taxa across the Caribbean. Taxa better adapted to nutrient-rich conditions were impacted most. Thus, the extinction is often attributed to declining planktic nutrients in Caribbean water due to isolation from the Pacific after the closure of the Central American Isthmus. The extinctions lagged closure by 1-2 Myr, however, leading some researchers to attribute increased extinction rates to climate change associated with the onset of northern hemisphere glaciation.
This study will integrate biotic and geochemical data to reveal the direct causes of the Caribbean extinction event and evaluate the evidence for the perceived delay using established and new paleoenvironmental proxies and the unprecedented breadth of sampling and depth of taxonomic analyses provided by the Panama Paleontology Project (PPP). Three hypotheses will be tested: (1) Doomed taxa survived in nutrient-rich refugia that persisted after Isthmus closure; extinction occurred when refugia diminished sufficiently. (2) Extinction was driven by cooling related to northern hemisphere glaciation. (3) Temporary survival of doomed taxa was unrelated to changes in nutrients or temperature, suggesting stochastic processes were responsible. To accomplish this, we will generate high-resolution stable isotopic (18O/16O, 13C/12C) profiles of ~90 gastropod shells from 26 fossil localities in the SWC dating between 5 and 1.4 Ma, supplemented by clumped isotope (13C18O/12C16O) and trace element (P/Ca, Sr/Ca, Ba/Ca) analyses, to determine past local temperature and nutrient availability.

This project will be the first to establish a well-constrained environmental system using the Tropical American fossil record and multiple high-resolution geochemical proxies to test a range of evolutionary hypotheses. These include the processes responsible for speciation, extinction, niche expansion, and evolutionary maintenance of sexual reproduction. Uniting biotic data with detailed paleoenvironmental data will reveal the root cause of the most geologically recent marine extinction and provide a real-world example with which to test models of the process of large-scale biodiversity loss. The modern anthropogenic fragmentation of natural habitats and populations mirrors the refugia that are purported to have delayed the extinction of SWC taxa in the Pliocene. Our data will evaluate this hypothesis and demonstrate whether this loss in biodiversity was directly related to environmental changes.

The project will integrate a Panama-based field experience into the undergraduate capstone course of the Environmental Programs in Geoscience at Texas A&M University (TAMU). Students will work in groups and conduct paleobiology and stable isotope research on samples they collect in Panama, and sample and analyze at TAMU. In addition to presenting results, students will write, peer-review, and revise research papers. The project will train a post-doctoral fellow and graduate student in interdisciplinary science and research mentoring. Finally, research findings will be presented at major national and international meetings and published in premier journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biologists warn that the current degradation and fragmentation of ecosystems will lead to extinctions long into the future – a process dubbed ‘Extinction debt’ – but making accurate predictions requires a much better understanding of how extinctions occur over long time scales. This project examines the Caribbean extinction event (1-2 Myr) that postdates the isolation of the Caribbean from the Tropical Eastern Pacfiic (TEP) by the formation of the Isthmus of Panama. During this event, extinction rates peaked between 35% and 100% in a variety of marine taxa across the Caribbean. Because taxa better adapted to high productivity conditions were impacted most, the extinction is often attributed to declining nutrient supplies in the Caribbean with isolation from the nutrient-rich Pacific after the uplift of the Isthmus of Panama. A conundrum is that extinctions lagged isolation by 1-2 Myr, leading some researchers to attribute increased extinction rates to climate change associated with the onset of northern hemisphere glaciation.

Our study examined the causes of the Caribbean extinction event and its timing. The study integrated biologic data with paleoenvironmental data based on over 5000 isotopic analyses (carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, and “clumped”) to determine the role of nutrient-rich refugia in allowing “doomed” taxa to persist for at least a million years after environmental perturbation (seaway closure) that devastated taxa dependent on highly productive waters.

The hypothesis of extinction delay is tied to a body of literature that argues for a 3-4 million year age for the complete emergence of the Isthmus of Panama. Recent literature has proposed a much earlier date for the emergence based on structural and sedimentological evidence. To examine the two hypotheses for the timing of Isthmus emergence, we compiled geological, isotopic (O, C, Nd), paleontological, and molecular data and successfully reaffirmed the later age in a major, widely-cited publication.

Our study is anchored with oxygen isotopic profiles (18O/16O) of gastropod shells from 37 fossil localities in the southwest Caribbean and TEP, dating between 5 and 1.4 Ma. Based on samples drilled at regular intervals in the direction of growth (Figure 1; image of shell with sampling pits), these profiles provide a record of seasonal temperature and salinity, and distinguish between rainy- and dry-season intervals of growth (Figure 2; isotopic profile). Comparisons between oxygen isotope data for nearshore mollusks and deep-sea microfossils reveal that Caribbean coastal ecosystems were, for a time, strongly influenced by input of river-derived nutrients that may have allowed doomed taxa to persist long after formation of the Isthmus of Panama (Figure 4; isotope summary figure). We hypothesize that extinction eventually occurred when river input declined because of southward movement of the Intertropical Convergence Zone in response to Northern Hemisphere cooling and glaciation. Preliminary nitrogen isotope analyses also suggest changes in nutrient dynamics with the closure of the interocean seaway.

The project also had an education mission; to provide (1) high-impact inquiry-based learning for undergraduate students, and (2) higher level training and mentoring to graduate students and post-doctoral researchers. Undergraduates in the capstone course (GEOS 405) of the Environmental Programs in Geoscience at TAMU were given a true international research experience. The PI’s and their graduate students and post-docs led two nine-day research field trips in Panama in March 2015 and 2016. These field trips focused on Panama-based research projects in which small teams of students designed, executed, wrote-up, and presented original research. Projects included studies of ocean acidification, ecotourism, paleoecology based on nitrogen isotopes, and the impact of harvesting on marine snail growth rates. In addition, two senior undergraduate students conducted independent research (GEOL 491) using oxygen- and carbon-isotope measurements of fossil mollusk shells to determine the environment of the Pacific coast of Panama a few 100,000 years ago. Lastly, two female graduate students and a female post-doctoral fellow received valuable training and mentoring in technique, writing, and oral presentation. Importantly, the graduate students and post-doc gained skills developing and executing research projects, and mentoring undergraduate researchers. 

We continue to publish our results and explore new techniques to study the Caribbean extinction. Two techniques of special interest, clumped isotopes and nitrogen isotopes, will allow us to determine absolute temperatures and paleo-foodwebs respectively. These studies hold great promise for unraveling the complex biologic changes associated with the emergence of the Isthmus of Panama and the separation of the Caribbean Sea and Pacific Ocean, and will, we believe, lead to better understanding of the relationship between environmental change and extinction.
